S5.T3.1.caption:
General information regarding public seizure scalp EEG datasets. In cases where published summaries lacked specific information, we examined the datasets to retrieve the information. N/A denotes that we failed to retrieve the information, even after manually inspecting the dataset. Characteristics and recording parameters of the EEG segments of publicly available EEG datasets. Note that the NSC-HK dataset has one EEG channel and no information on how it was selected or which placement it corresponds to. In cases where published summaries lacked specific information, we examined the datasets to retrieve the information.
  The recording lengths vary between segments.
  This is the minimum sampling frequency.  PRISMA flowchart. Reasons for exclusion of reports are numbered following the list of exclusion criteria provided above. ‘Other’ includes retracted articles, studies that are not seizure detection and studies that did not meet reasonable quality standards. (Created with BioRender,  ) Standard pipeline for automated seizure detection using ML algorithms (Created with BioRender,  ) Example of popular time-series features used to discriminate between ictal and non-ictal EEG segments. Even though features can be extracted from data belonging to any domain, providing it has the correct dimensions, they are often used in one domain only. The features in the table below are grouped by the domain within which they are most commonly applied. Feature-based ML methods from systematic review of literature for seizure detection in scalp EEG data continued - Feature-based ML methods from systematic review of literature for seizure detection in scalp EEG data continued - Feature-based ML methods from systematic review of literature for seizure detection in scalp EEG data DL methods from systematic review of literature for seizure detection in scalp EEG data continued - DL methods from systematic review of literature for seizure detection in scalp EEG data continued - DL methods from systematic review of literature for seizure detection in scalp EEG data continued - DL methods from systematic review of literature for seizure detection in scalp EEG data continued - DL methods from systematic review of literature for seizure detection in scalp EEG data Confusion matrix of a binary seizure detection algorithm. Ictal segments are labeled as being positive and non-ictal segments as negative. TP = true positive, FP = false positive, FN = false negative, TN = true negative. (Created with BioRender,  ) Search strategy for each repository. Each search string corresponds to equivalent inclusion criteria. They are formatted to fit the database specific search tool’s syntax. Table of common metrics used to evaluate the performance of ML algorithms. Note: sensitivity is also known as   and specificity as
S5.T3.1.table:
Domain Features
Time domain Absolute energy, energy ratio
Mean and variance over the autocorrelation for different lags, partial autocorrelation
Autoregressive coefficients
Hjorth activity, mobility, and complexity, line length
Mean, median, mode, maximum, minimum, mean, standard deviation, variance, quantile range, kurtosis
Permutation entropy, Shannon entropy, spectral entropy, approximate entropy, Sample entropy, Fuzzi entropy, Renyi entropy
Frequency domain Fourier transform aggregate and coefficients, band power
Time-frequency domain Continuous wavelet coefficients and peaks
Network domain Weighted degree, clustering coefficient, harmonic centrality, modularity, closeness centrality, eigenvector centrality
TAES=Sens−α×FAs24⁢hr−β×N/19TAESSens𝛼subscriptFAs24hr𝛽𝑁19\textnormal{TAES}=\textnormal{Sens}-\alpha\times\textnormal{FAs}_{24% \textnormal{hr}}-\beta\times N/19TAES = Sens - italic_α × FAs start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 24 hr end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_β × italic_N / 19
Name Formula Description
 
Accuracy TP + TNTP + TN + FN + FPTP + TNTP + TN + FN + FP\begin{aligned} \frac{\text{TP + TN}}{\text{TP + TN + FN + FP}}\end{aligned}start_ROW start_CELL divide start_ARG TP + TN end_ARG start_ARG TP + TN + FN + FP end_ARG end_CELL end_ROW Proportion of correctly classified instances or correct predictions out of the total number of instances in the dataset
Sensitivity, Recall TPTP + FNTPTP + FN\begin{aligned} \frac{\text{TP}}{\text{TP + FN}}\end{aligned}start_ROW start_CELL divide start_ARG TP end_ARG start_ARG TP + FN end_ARG end_CELL end_ROW Evaluate how well a classification algorithms identifies positive instances
Specificity TNTN + FPTNTN + FP\begin{aligned} \frac{\text{TN}}{\text{TN + FP}}\end{aligned}start_ROW start_CELL divide start_ARG TN end_ARG start_ARG TN + FP end_ARG end_CELL end_ROW Evaluate how well a classification algorithms identifies negative instances
Precision TPTP + FPTPTP + FP\begin{aligned} \frac{\text{TP}}{\text{TP + FP}}\end{aligned}start_ROW start_CELL divide start_ARG TP end_ARG start_ARG TP + FP end_ARG end_CELL end_ROW Proportion of positive predictions that are actually true positives
F1 2 * Precision * RecallPrecision + Recall2 * Precision * RecallPrecision + Recall\begin{aligned} \frac{\text{2 * Precision * Recall}}{\text{Precision + Recall}% }\end{aligned}start_ROW start_CELL divide start_ARG 2 * Precision * Recall end_ARG start_ARG Precision + Recall end_ARG end_CELL end_ROW It combines both precision and recall to provide a balanced view of a model’s performance
